title: How to Set up a Drywall Ceiling

steps.headline: Unless you got a drywall lift, were going to built a T-brace from 2x4's.
steps.description: The top piece should be 3 feet (0.9 m) wide, and the long piece should be the same height as the ceiling itself.

steps.headline: Install the drywall lengthwise on the joist for maximum structure strength.
The first piece of drywall that you put up is the most important.
steps.description: If that piece is not square, every other piece will be off a little too.

steps.headline: Use an electric drywall screw gun to fasten the drywall to the joist.
steps.description: Place the screw about every 6 inches (15.2 cm) apart on the joist. Make sure that you sink the screw far enough. Run a taping knife on top of the screw to see if its deep enough, the knife shouldn't hit the screw.

steps.headline: When it comes time to cut the drywall, use a utility knife along with a straightedge, some a made specially for drywall.
steps.description: Only score the   one side of the drywall, snap it, and then cut the back side.

text: Unless you got a drywall lift, were going to built a T-brace from 2x4's. The top piece should be 3 feet (0.9 m) wide, and the long piece should be the same height as the ceiling itself. Install the drywall lengthwise on the joist for maximum structure strength.  The first piece of drywall that you put up is the most important. If that piece is not square, every other piece will be off a little too. Use an electric drywall screw gun to fasten the drywall to the joist. Place the screw about every 6 inches (15.2 cm) apart on the joist. Make sure that you sink the screw far enough. Run a taping knife on top of the screw to see if its deep enough, the knife shouldn't hit the screw. When it comes time to cut the drywall, use a utility knife along with a straightedge, some a made specially for drywall. Only score the   one side of the drywall, snap it, and then cut the back side.
